On 29 January, hundreds of people protested over poor infrastructure in [[Jeddah]] on following flooding<ref name="Montreal" /><ref name="Reuters_Dozens_detained" /> and an [[internet|online]] campaign for major political and economic changes started. Forty women demonstrated on 5 February for the release of prisoners held without trial.<ref name="swiss_Saudi_5Feb" /> Plans were made for a "Day of Rage" on 11 March 2011, contributing to a rise in oil prices.<ref name="saudirage11March" />
+
'''2011 Saudi Arabian protests''' influenced by the [[2010â2011 Middle East and North Africa protests]] took place in '''Saudi Arabia in early 2011'''. On 29 January, hundreds of people protested over poor infrastructure in [[Jeddah]] on following flooding<ref name="Montreal" /><ref name="Reuters_Dozens_detained" /> and an [[internet|online]] campaign for major political and economic changes started. Forty women demonstrated on 5 February for the release of prisoners held without trial.<ref name="swiss_Saudi_5Feb" /> Plans were made for a "Day of Rage" on 11 March 2011, contributing to a rise in oil prices.<ref name="saudirage11March" />
==Background==
==Background==
{{main|Politics of Saudi Arabia}}
{{main|Politics of Saudi Arabia}}
â
The politics of Saudi Arabia takes place in a framework of a particular form of [[absolute monarchy]] whereby the [[King of Saudi Arabia]] is both [[head of state]] and the [[head of government]], but where decisions are to a large extent made on the basis of consultation among the senior princes, with the King functioning as ''primus inter pares'' and ultimate arbiter. The Basic Law adopted in 1992 declared that Saudi Arabia is a monarchy ruled by the male descendants of King [[Abd Al Aziz Al Saud]], and that the [[Qur'an]] is the constitution of the country, which is governed on the basis of [[Islam]]ic law ([[Sharia|Shari'a]]).
+
The politics of Saudi Arabia takes place in a framework of a particular form of [[absolute monarchy]] whereby the [[King of Saudi Arabia]] is both [[head of state]] and the [[head of government]], but where decisions are to a large extent made on the basis of consultation among the senior princes, with the King functioning as ''primus inter pares'' and ultimate arbiter. The Basic Law adopted in 1992 declared that Saudi Arabia is a monarchy ruled by the male descendants of King [[Abd Al Aziz Al Saud]], and that the [[Qur'an]] is the constitution of the country, which is governed on the basis of [[Islam]]ic law ([[Sharia|Shari'a]]).
â   â
==Protests==
 
An unidentified 65-year-old man died on 21 January after setting himself on fire in the town of [[Samtah]], [[Jizan]]. This was apparently the kingdom's first known case of self-immolation.<ref name="saudi_selfimmo65yr">{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12260465|title=Man dies after setting himself on fire in Saudi Arabia|author=|date=23 January 2011 |work=|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=23 January 2011 }}</ref><ref name="saudi2">{{cite web|url=http://sundaytimes.lk/world-news/4231-man-dies-in-possible-first-self-immolation-in-saudi|title=Man dies in possible first self-immolation in Saudi |author=Mohideen Mifthah |date=22 January 2011 |work=|publisher=The Sunday Times, http://sundaytimes.lk/|accessdate=23 January 2011 }}</ref>
An unidentified 65-year-old man died on 21 January after setting himself on fire in the town of [[Samtah]], [[Jizan]]. This was apparently the kingdom's first known case of self-immolation.<ref name="saudi_selfimmo65yr">{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12260465|title=Man dies after setting himself on fire in Saudi Arabia|author=|date=23 January 2011 |work=|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=23 January 2011 }}</ref><ref name="saudi2">{{cite web|url=http://sundaytimes.lk/world-news/4231-man-dies-in-possible-first-self-immolation-in-saudi|title=Man dies in possible first self-immolation in Saudi |author=Mohideen Mifthah |date=22 January 2011 |work=|publisher=The Sunday Times, http://sundaytimes.lk/|accessdate=23 January 2011 }}</ref>
  +
==Protests==
  +
=== 29 January ===
On 29 January, hundreds of protesters gathered in the city of [[Jeddah]] in a rare display of criticism against the city's poor infrastructure after deadly floods swept through the city, killing eleven people.<ref name="Montreal">{{cite web|url=http://www.montrealgazette.com/news/Flood+sparks+rare+action/4189873/story.html|title=Flood sparks rare action|author=|date=29 January 2011 |work=|publisher=[[The Gazette (Montreal)|Montreal Gazette]] |accessdate=29 January 2011 }}</ref> Police stopped the demonstration about 15 minutes after it started. About 30 to 50 people were arrested.<ref name="Reuters_Dozens_detained">{{cite news | title=Dozens detained in Saudi over flood protests | date=2011-01-29 | publisher=[[The Peninsula (newspaper)|The Peninsula]] (Qatar)/[[Thomson-Reuters]] | url=http://www.thepeninsulaqatar.com/middle-east/140720-dozens-detained-in-saudi-over-flood-protests.html |accessdate=2011-01-31 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w9qUZeyR |archivedate=2011-01-31 |deadurl=no }}</ref> On the same day, an online campaign started on [[Facebook]], making demands that included calling for Saudi Arabia to become a constitutional monarchy, and for "an end to corruption, an even distribution of wealth, and a serious solution for unemployment".<ref name="swiss_Saudi_5Feb" />
On 29 January, hundreds of protesters gathered in the city of [[Jeddah]] in a rare display of criticism against the city's poor infrastructure after deadly floods swept through the city, killing eleven people.<ref name="Montreal">{{cite web|url=http://www.montrealgazette.com/news/Flood+sparks+rare+action/4189873/story.html|title=Flood sparks rare action|author=|date=29 January 2011 |work=|publisher=[[The Gazette (Montreal)|Montreal Gazette]] |accessdate=29 January 2011 }}</ref> Police stopped the demonstration about 15 minutes after it started. About 30 to 50 people were arrested.<ref name="Reuters_Dozens_detained">{{cite news | title=Dozens detained in Saudi over flood protests | date=2011-01-29 | publisher=[[The Peninsula (newspaper)|The Peninsula]] (Qatar)/[[Thomson-Reuters]] | url=http://www.thepeninsulaqatar.com/middle-east/140720-dozens-detained-in-saudi-over-flood-protests.html |accessdate=2011-01-31 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w9qUZeyR |archivedate=2011-01-31 |deadurl=no }}</ref> On the same day, an online campaign started on [[Facebook]], making demands that included calling for Saudi Arabia to become a constitutional monarchy, and for "an end to corruption, an even distribution of wealth, and a serious solution for unemployment".<ref name="swiss_Saudi_5Feb" />
  +
=== 5 February ===
On 5 February, about 40 women wearing black clothes demonstrated in [[Riyadh]], calling for the release of prisoners held without trial.<ref name="swiss_Saudi_5Feb">{{cite news | first=Ulf | last= Laessing |coauthors=Asma Alsharif | pages= | language =| title= | date=2011-02-05 | publisher=[[Swiss Info]]/[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/news/international/Saudi_women_protest,_web_activists_call_for_reform.html?cid=29428092 |accessdate=2011-02-16 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wYAoCCPC |archivedate=2011-02-16 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
On 5 February, about 40 women wearing black clothes demonstrated in [[Riyadh]], calling for the release of prisoners held without trial.<ref name="swiss_Saudi_5Feb">{{cite news | first=Ulf | last= Laessing |coauthors=Asma Alsharif | pages= | language =| title= | date=2011-02-05 | publisher=[[Swiss Info]]/[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/news/international/Saudi_women_protest,_web_activists_call_for_reform.html?cid=29428092 |accessdate=2011-02-16 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wYAoCCPC |archivedate=2011-02-16 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
â
===11 March "Day of Rage"===
+
=== 10 February ===
  +
On 10 February, a [[Thomson Reuters]] report claimed that 10 intellectuals, [[human rights in Saudi Arabia|human rights]] activists and lawyers came together to create the [[Umma Islamic Party]] â considered to be the first political party in Saudi Arabia since the 1990s â to demand the end of [[absolute monarchy]] in the country.<ref name="threuters_umma_created">{{cite news | first=Ulf | last=Laessing| pages= | language =| title=Pro-reform Saudi activists launch political party | date=2011-02-10 | publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/10/us-saudi-opposition-idUSTRE71942L20110210?sp=true |accessdate=2011-02-11 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wQOpuC8A |archivedate=2011-02-11 |deadurl=no }}</ref> On 18 February, all ten founding members of the party were arrested and ordered to withdraw demands for political reform in exchange for their release.<ref>{{cite news|author=Post Store |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/02/18/AR2011021802641.html |title=Saudi authorites detain founders of new party |publisher=Washington Post |date=2011-02-18 |accessdate=2011-02-19 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5whAiOr55 |archivedate=2011-02-22 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
  +   +
=== 23 February ===
  +
On 23 February, Saudi Arabia's King Abdullah, after returning to the country following three months spent abroad for health treatment, announced a series of benefits for citizens amounting to $10.7 billion. These include funding to offset high inflation and to aid young unemployed people and Saudi citizens studying abroad, as well the writing off some loans. As part of the Saudi scheme, state employees will see their incomes increase by 15 per cent, and additional cash has also been made available for housing loans. No political reforms were announced as part of the package, though the 86-year-old monarch did pardon some prisoners indicted in financial crimes.<ref>{{cite news |title=Saudi king announces new benefits |author=[[Al-Jazeera English]] |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/2011223105328424268.html |newspaper= |date=23 February 2011 |accessdate=23 February 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
=== 11 March - "Day of Rage" ===
A "Day of Rage" is planned by Saudi Arabians on 11 March 2011.<ref name="saudirage11March">{{cite news | first= Richard |last=Spencer |coauthors= James Kirkup, Nabila Ramdani | pages= | language =| title=Libya: Muammar Gaddafi's regime on the brink of collapse | date=2011-02-21 | publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]] | url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8339435/Libya-Muammar-Gaddafis-regime-on-the-brink-of-collapse.html |accessdate=2011-02-22 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wh6l0B7O |archivedate=2011-02-22 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
A "Day of Rage" is planned by Saudi Arabians on 11 March 2011.<ref name="saudirage11March">{{cite news | first= Richard |last=Spencer |coauthors= James Kirkup, Nabila Ramdani | pages= | language =| title=Libya: Muammar Gaddafi's regime on the brink of collapse | date=2011-02-21 | publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]] | url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8339435/Libya-Muammar-Gaddafis-regime-on-the-brink-of-collapse.html |accessdate=2011-02-22 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wh6l0B7O |archivedate=2011-02-22 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
